presentation.title: Introduction
presentation.author: Dzenan Ridjanovic
presentation.objective: The objective of this spiral is to introduce Modelibra and Wicket frameworks. More specifically, the objective is to define a simple domain model with only one concept and to create a simple web application based on the model that will display the concept data.

slide.title: Objective
slide.subTitle: Modelibra & Wicket
slide.purpose: The objective is to introduce Modelibra and Wicket frameworks by defining a simple domain model and creating a minimal web application.

point.text: The objective is to introduce Modelibra and Wicket frameworks by defining a simple domain model and creating a minimal web application.
Framework is a base for developing software faster and better in a specific domain.
Pattern is a reusable design and code for a specific problem in a certain context.
Model View Controller (MVC) is one of the most popular design patterns.

A web application has two major parts: a model of data in a certain domain and data views presented in web pages. Web pages are constructed dynamically, on a server, based on different data and then sent to a client browser.
Two frameworks, Modelibra and Wicket, are used to develop web applications in a productive way.
Modelibra is a domain model Java framework. A domain model is a model of specific domain classes that describe the core data and their behavior.
Wicket is a web application framework for creating dynamic web pages by using web components. It uses only two technologies: Java and HTML.
Web application configuration file: web.xml.
Modelibra configuration file: dm-config.xml
Jetty configuration file: jetty-config.xml.
Java Start class to start Jetty.
Domain model: Concept (entity, entities), concept properties, concept neighbors, concept identifiers (oid, unique).
In this spiral, the domain model has only one concept: Url.
Main memory model.
Model persistency (xml, db).
Magic Models to design domain models.
Modelibra Domain application (Model) to configure domain models.
Model configuration: dm-config.xml, dm-config.dtd.
Default configuration context: dmConfig.properties.
Model "database": UrlsDb.
Url concept entity class: Url. Url concept entities class: Urls.
Simple tests: UrlsDb.
Application class: UrlsApp.
Application configuration: web.xml, dm-config.xml.
Application home page: HoemPage.
Wicket model vs. Modelibra model.
Java class vs. Java class html. Wicket ids to link Java class components with the Java class html page elements.
Request/response cycle. index.html
XHTML
CSS

presentation.title: Web Page Links
presentation.author: Dzenan Ridjanovic
presentation.objective: The objective of this web application spiral, urls01, is to introduce different types of web page links so that our application may have more than one web page. At the same time, the look of the web pages is improved using the CSS (Cascading Style Sheets) definitions.

point.text: The objective of this web application spiral, urls01, is to introduce different types of web page links so that our application may have more than one web page. At the same time, the look of the web pages is improved using the CSS (Cascading Style Sheets) definitions.

Each url in the list has an external (to this application) web page link, the page short description and the Display link that displays, in a new page called UrlPage, all url properties: link, description and the new category property. A user may follow the url link to display the external web page, or to return to the home page.
As in the previous spiral, the urls are loaded from the xml file. A user still can neither add new urls nor modify the existing ones.

slide.title: Spiral
slide.subTitle: Initial Changes
slide.purpose: How to start a new spiral.

point.text: The urls00 spiral is copied outside of Eclipse and its name is changed in the copied version to urls01.
Before the project is imported, the Eclipse .project file is opened with a text editor and the project name is modified to urls01.

Within Eclipse, after the project is imported, the links00.txt is selected and from the pop-up menu the Refactor/Rename... choice is used to rename the file to links01.txt. Similarly, urls01.txt is updated to urls02.txt.
In jetty-config.xml, the first call application argument is changed to /urls01.
The HomePage class is modified to have less code without loosing functionality.
A Java anonymous class is used to construct the ListView component that is then added to the page.
An anonymous class is essentially a local (inner) class without a name.
The populateItem method implements the corresponding abstract method in the Wicket ListView class.
First, the url object is extracted from the list item.
Second, the Wicket ExternalLink and Label components are created and added to the list item.

Third, a page link, that is bookmarkable by a web browser, is created.
The page link has the selected url oid parameter. This parameter will be used, when a user clicks on the link, in the UrlDisplayPage class to obtain the url.
The ExternalLink component represents a simple anchor link body pointing to any URL.
ExternalLink is used for links to destinations outside of Wicket.
The external link constructor has three arguments.
The first one, "link", is the component id that is used to link the component with the anchor a element in the corresponding HTML page Link .
The second argument is the link URL (href attribute).
The third argument is the link display text (<a> element body label).
The BookmarkablePageLink component creates a stable link which can be cached in a web browser and used at a later time.
As almost all other Wicket components it has its id: "urlDisplay" (the constructor`s first argument).
The second argument is the page class to link to: UrlDisplayPage.class.

The BookmarkablePageLink object may have one or more web page request parameters (String, int, long) that are set by the setParameter method. When a user clicks on the link, the web page represented by the UrlDisplayPage class will be shown.
The final keyword can be applied to four Java concepts:
1. variables: a final variable can be set only once.
2. fields: a final field can be set only once, by a constructor of the class which defines it.
3. methods: a final method cannot be overridden.
4. classes: a final class cannot be extended.
The final keyword limits defaults, for example, the ability to override a method.
As a class that represents a bookmarkable web page, the UrlDisplayPage constructor has one argument for PageParameters.
The oid number, set in the populateItem method, is retrieved from parameters by the getLong method using the "oid" parameter name.
Based on the oid number, the url objects is obtained from the application domain model entry and passed as an argument to the createComponents method.
The page has four components: the home page link, the category and description labels, and the external link.
Since UrlDisplayPage extends the Wicket WebPage component, the home link is obtained by the inherited homePageLink method.
For each web application concept Wicket has a corresponding component.
A web application has pages and one of them is the home page.
A web page may be composed of text (labels), links, data in a list view, and other components.
For each web application concept, Wicket has a component in a form of a Java class.
For a web application there is WebApplication.
For a web page, there is WebPage.
For a text label, there is Label.
For an external link, there is ExternalLink.
For a list view of data, there is ListView.
You cannot find more natural correspondence between web application concepts and web framework components.
A Wicket component has an identifier (id) that is used to establish a correspondence between the component and HTML element where the component value(s) will be displayed.
The component value comes from the component model.

The simplest case is a Label with a static String model:
new Label("category", "Framework")

A Label with a dynamic model is created by
new Label("category", url.getCategory())
The "category" text is the label id, and the String return of the url.getCategory() method is the label model.
The category id is found in the corresponding HTML file within the table td element. Category
Wicket uses the component model to replace the corresponding (based on the component id) element body with the model value. Thus, the Category text will be replaced by whatever getCategory() returns.
Wicket model must implement wicket.model.IModel.
Some components have a convenience constructor that creates a proper model for you.
With the Label class, you can just provide a string, which is then wrapped into a simple model for the label to use.

The label model may be constructed explicitly as in
new Label("linkId", new PropertyModel(url, "link"))
In this case, the Label component will replace the body of the tag, it is attached to, with the link property of the given url object.
The PropertyModel class is a part of the wicket.model package. PropertytModel implements wicket.model.IModel.
The PropertyModel class is used to dynamically access a model using an OGNL expression.
A property name is a simple OGNL expression.

OGNL stands for Object Graph Navigation Language (http://www.ognl.org/).
It is an expression and binding language for getting and setting properties of Java objects.
Wicket and Modelibra use POJO objects. POJO is an acronym for Plain Old Java Object. The name is used to emphasize that the object in question is not somehow special but an ordinary Java Object
The link property has a new type. It is not any more String but java.net.URL.
The link property must be configured properly in the dm-config.xml file.
The Url class has a new property, category, with the corresponding get and set methods.
The dm-config.xml configuration is updated to include the new property description.
The HTML home page displays data in a nicer way by using the app.css file that is located in the application root directory (urls01).
The reference to the CSS file is made by the link element within the head element.
Both external and internal links are handled by the HTML <a> tag.
A cascading style sheet (CSS) is made up of style rules that tell a browser how to present a web page.

The div element is used to make a reference to a CSS class definition and to determine the scope of the definition. The div element defines a block of HTML. It is commonly used to apply CSS to a page section.

A CSS rule is made up of a selector, here box-title, and the style to be applied to the selector. The style is defined by properties. A property takes a value that describes how the selector should be presented.
Any HTML element is a possible CSS selector. The selector is simply the element that is linked to a particular style.
A simple selector can have different classes, thus allowing the same element to have different styles. For example, a home page may have different formatting from other web pages.
Classes may also be declared without an associated HTML element.
A good practice is to name classes according to their function rather than their appearance.

Contextual selectors are two or more simple selectors separated by white space. These selectors can be assigned normal properties and, due to the rules of cascading order, they will take precedence over simple selectors.
In order to decrease repetitious statements within style sheets, grouping of selectors and declarations is allowed.

Pseudo-classes are special "classes" that are automatically recognized by CSS-supporting browsers. Pseudo-classes distinguish among different element types (e.g., visited links and active links represent two types of anchors).

presentation.title: Page Decomposition
presentation.author: Dzenan Ridjanovic
presentation.objective: The objective of this spiral is to design web pages from panels and panels from Wicket components or from components inherited from Wicket components. A panel is a page section.

point.text: The objective of this spiral is to design web pages from panels and panels from Wicket components or from components inherited from Wicket components. A panel is a page section.

Object-oriented programming is often touted as promoting software reuse. There are two basic techniques that make object-oriented software more reusable: decomposition and inheritance.
Decomposition provides modularity and information-hiding and inheritance promotes code reuse, since code shared by several classes can be placed in their common superclass.

A specific web page, which extends the Wicket WebPage component, is decomposed into specific panels, and panels are decomposed into Wicket components. If a Wicket component does not provide exactly what we want, we may create our own component that inherits the component common behavior and adds some specific details needed in our application. In the same way, a specific page panel class extends the Wicket Panel component and adds some specific properties.
An inheritance hierarchy may have several levels providing even an inheritance tree. A node from the tree is then reused in different contexts, either pages or page panels.
There are now two different ways of consulting urls.
The first way, from the previous spiral, is a list of urls from which a single url may be displayed in a new page by using the Display link.
The second way is a list of urls with an additional link, Url, to show the selected url within the same page.

In order to make those two similar but different views of consulting urls, both (de)composition and inheritance will be used. In this way, common things are reused in different contexts. This will produce quite a few small classes, but each one with a clear design pattern. Program components must be designed for reusability. The price to pay is more effort to produce components, but the reusability payoff is much more important.
HomePage has three links: the home page link, the link that displays a table of urls, and the link that displays a table of urls with a possibility to display in full details the selected url.

Since the home page link references the same page where it is added as a page component, by default, the link is active. To make it inactive (to be displayed as italics text), the setAutoEnable method is used.
The UrlDisplaySelectionTablePage class is composed of two panels: UrlDisplaySelectionTablePanel and UrlDisplayPanel.

Visually, the page is divided into two sections. On the left, there is a list of urls and on the right the selected url. A url is selected by clicking on the corresponding Url link. When the list is displayed for the first time, the first url in the list is shown.

The default constructor obtains the urls and the first url, and passes those two objects to the createComponents private method. Without the empty list exception case, there would be only three lines of code for three components: the home page link, the UrlDisplaySelectionTablePanel component and the UrlDisplayPanel component.
When there are no urls, i.e., when the urls object is empty, the first url is null. In that case, the UrlDisplayPanel component must be constructed and added to the page, but it is made invisible.
The corresponding UrlDisplaySelectionTablePage.html page is trivial.

The special space character ( ) is used to enforce one space before the "button" look a like link. The left-column and the right-column CSS classes present two components in a two column page template. The float property is used to align the two columns.

The major promise that came with CSS was that we would no longer use tables for page layouts, and would instead control the positions and dimensions of page elements by div elements and div classes that apply float and other properties.

The div tag is a block level element that can contain almost anything. Block level elements are used to format whole blocks of text. They default to 100% of the available screen width and add line breaks between each other and they will stack up underneath one another unless you position them in some way.

The simplest way to align page sections is to use the CSS float property. You can float any element left or right, and it will align itself over to the side of whatever element it is contained within.
The UrlDisplayPage class is decomposed into two components: the home page link and the url display panel.
Both UrlDisplaySelectionTablePage and UrlDisplayPage reuse the UrlDisplayPanel component.

The page decomposition into panels and some simple components, such as page links, produces small page classes and small HTML pages, which can be easily programmed, explained, maintained and even reused.
Page specific panels extend the Wicket Panel component. When there are similar but different page panels, they may inherit from each other to create even a tree of reusable panels.

A panel will inherit from another panel if it contains exactly the same components as the inheritance parent with a few additional components specific to the inheritance child. Those additional components may be Wicket predefined components and/or other specific components that can also be panels.
For example, the UrlDisplayTablePanel inherits from Panel and has only one specific UrlDisplayTableListView component.
The UrlDisplayTableListView extends the Wicket ListView class. It specializes the Wicket component by adding two other Wicket components: ExternalLink and BookmarkablePageLink.
The UrlDisplayTableListView constructor has the component id and urls parameters. The id and the list of urls are passed as arguments to the ListView constructor.
Since the list contains url objects, the list item (row) is casted back to Url that is then used to create and add two links to the item.

This time, the url category is not shown, neither the external link URL. Instead, the url short description is displayed as the external link. The org.dmlite.util.text.TextHandler utility class from Modelibra is used to extract the first 60 description characters.
The Wicket Panel class has its own HTML markup. If a panel is reused in different pages, the one and only one panel markup is reused as well.

The panel markup starts with
<html xmlns:wicket>
<wicket:panel>
and ends with
</wicket:panel> .
</html>

The UrlDisplayPanel inherits from Panel and has three Wicket components: Label, ExternalLink and MultiLineLabel. If the given url is null, the components will not be created, but the empty panel will be.

The MultiLineLabel is a new Wicket component. Unlike Label it shows text that spans multiple lines by inserting line breaks (
elements) for newlines and paragraph markers (

elements) for sequences of more than one newline.
The UrlDisplaySelectionTablePanel class has only one specific component, the UrlDisplaySelectionTableListView list view.

The UrlDisplaySelectionTableListView extends the specific UrlDisplayTableListView class and adds a link to the UrlDisplaySelectionTablePage page, the same page where the UrlDisplaySelectionTablePanel panel is located.

The super keyword in the UrlDisplaySelectionTableListView constructor is used to first populate the item by the inheritance parent populateItem method. Then the link to UrlDisplaySelectionTablePage is added to the item. The link is a convenience static method in the UrlDisplaySelectionTablePage class that returns a link to UrlDisplaySelectionTablePage.

The Wicket PageLink component has a constructor that uses the IPageLink interface as the second argument for constructing a page lazily. When a user clicks on the link, a new page will be created at that time by the getPage method of the IPageLink interface. The anonymous class implements the two interface methods. The getPageIdentity method returns the page class.

presentation.title: Rapid Development of Web Applications with Web Components
presentation.author: Dzenan Ridjanovic
presentation.objective: To give a presentation of 15 minutes at the CISSE 2006 Web Conference.
presentation.description: This paper provides a brief overview of two frameworks, Modelibra and ModelibraWicket, which are used to develop dynamic web applications in a relatively short amount of time. Modelibra is a framework that facilitates the definition and the use of domain models in Java. ModelibraWicket is a rapid application development framework that uses Modelibra for domain models and Wicket for application views. Wicket is a web framework that provides web components to construct, in an object oriented way, web concepts, such as web pages and page sections. ModelibraWicket interprets the application model and creates default web pages based on the model.

slide.title: Domain Model Driven Development of Web Applications
slide.subTitle: Dzenan Ridjanovic
slide.purpose: The 6th OOPSLA Workshop on Domain-Specific Modeling

point.text: Modelibra framework.
ModelibraWicket web framework.
Java and Wicket web framework used for development.

slide.title: Modelibra
slide.subTitle: Motivation
slide.purpose: To explain why I have developed the Modelibra (Modelibra) framework.

point.text: As a professor I, and my students, develop software (mostly web applications). I needed something easy to learn and use in order to represent application (domain) models in Java.
I wanted to be able to install and run a student's project quickly.
I wished my students spent less time programming and more time responding to what users want.

slide.title: Modelibra
slide.subTitle: Objectives
slide.purpose: To focus on the essence of Modelibra.

point.text: Domain model configuration in XML.
Model configuration use as a domain model.
Default context for a new domain model.
Default XML persistence of domain objects.
Complete domain model available in main memory.
Domain model entry points (concepts).
Traversal of objects from entry concepts by following relationships.
Selection and ordering of objects.

slide.title: Domain Model
slide.subTitle: Basics
slide.purpose: To explain what a domain model is in Modelibra.

point.text: A domain model is a representation of user concepts, concept properties and relationships between concepts.
A domain model is represented in Modelibra as the DomainModel Java class that implements the IDomainModel interface.

A domain model concept is described by its properties and neighbors. The oid property is mandatory. It is used as an artificial identifier and is managed by Modelibra. In addition, a concept may have at most one user oriented identifier (id) that consists of the concept properties and/or neighbors.
A concept is represented in Modelibra as two Java classes, one for Entity and the other for Entities (or OrderedEntities if an order of entities is important).
The Entity class implements the IEntity interface.
The Entities class implements the IEntities interface.
A domain model has a few concepts that are entry points. The access to concept entities is provided only through the entry points.

slide.title: ModelibraWicket
slide.subTitle: Motivation
slide.purpose: To explain the need for dmRad.

point.text: A default web application for the given domain model.
A domain model default web application is the best way to validate the domain model.
Web components for a specific page composition.
The domain model configuration as a driving force.
The domain model configuration with some basic view presentation properties.
Web components tightly linked to a domain model.
The domain model configuration is used to find the model entry points and to provide a web page for each entry point, either for the display or for the update of data.
An entry point is a collection of entities and it is presented in a web page as a table, a list, or a slide show of entities.
The traversal of the domain model is done by navigating from an entry entity to neighbor entities following the parent-child neighbor directions.
ModelibraWicket has a collection of web components that may be easily reused in specific web applications to display or update entities.
Web components have an intimate knowledge of the domain model.
Web components use the Wicket web framework for the basic components.
Code generation of domain model configuration and specific Java classes.
Object database persistence with db4o has already been done. Relational database persistence is in making using JDBC directly.
More web components.
Developing ModelibraWicket for Java Swing.

presentation.title: Modelibra Software Family
presentation.author: Dzenan Ridjanovic
presentation.objective: To provide an introduction to the Modelibra family of frameworks and tools.
presentation.description: Modelibra is a domain model framework for rapid application development. A domain model may be designed, generated, and validated as a web application. Modelibra uses the Wicket web framework for generic web components that are views of model concepts. The generic web components may be mixed with specific web components to develop a professional Wicket application.

point.explanation:
This is the first line. This should be in the second line.
And this should be in new paragraph. Use WebDeveloper plugin for Firefox and Outline->Current Element to check.

point.text: This is achieved by using MultiLineLabel. Unlike Label, MultiLineLabel shows text that spans multiple lines by inserting line breaks (BR tags) for newlines and paragraph markers (P tags) for sequences of more than one newline.
If MultiLine label component is matched with HTML pre tag in HTML template, that preserves whitespace, which is convenient for code snippets.
However there is a problem with HTML pre tag in case text line exceeds the container width it goes out. Check the following link for css solution which is unfortunately not valid css
Wrapping Text Inside PRE HTML Tags
Wicket escapes by default, so if you enter italic text You get the same display text. Using setEscapeModelStrings(false); prevents escaping.
With this it is possible to allow users to do some basic text formating. Try to use setEscapeModelStrings(false); for MultiLineLabel in PointDisplayTableListView, and this text should be italic
However, this should be allowed only for text properties that pass some validation to prevent user entering some malicious code (javascript, spam links...). i.e allow just b and i tags
